articles.title: Svelte 5 is Alive
articles.description: The long awaited next major release of Svelte, the compiler-driven JS UI framework, is the ‚Äúmost significant release in the project‚Äôs history‚Äù, while remaining largely backwards compatible. A big addition is runes for explicitly declaring reactive state, but there‚Äôs much more besides. The official svelte.dev site has also undergone a big rebuild to act as an ‚Äòomnisite‚Äô for all things Svelte.
articles.author: The Svelte Team

articles.title: GenAIScript: Microsoft's Generative AI Scripting Environment
articles.description: Microsoft is really poking at AI from all angles. TypeChat introduced a type-safe way to talk to LLMs; now GenAIScript offers a JavaScript-powered way to programmatically assemble prompts and process responses. They claim it ‚Äúbrings essential LLM prompt tooling into a cohesive scripting environment.‚Äù
articles.author: Microsoft

articles.title: Next.js 15 Released
articles.description: It‚Äôs a big week for the popular (some may even argue default) React framework with Next.js Conf starting today, as well as this release. It includes a codemod CLI for easier upgrading, async request APIs, alignment with React 19, and more.
articles.author: Vercel

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†Build a Sonic Infinite Runner Game Using Kaplay
articles.description: A two hour walkthrough of using the Kaplay game library (formerly known as Kaboom.js) to build a complete, if simple, Sonic-branded game. You can also play it here.
articles.author: JSLegendDev

articles.title: Why I‚Äôm Skeptical of Rewriting JavaScript Tools in ‚ÄúFaster‚Äù¬†Languages
articles.description: Rewriting common JS infrastructure / build tools in ‚Äòfaster‚Äô languages like Rust, Zig or Go has become popular in recent years, but is it  necessary, asks Nolan?
articles.author: Nolan Lawson

articles.title: How to Create a Modern SPA with Django and Vue
articles.description: If you can handle some Python in your life, Django is a powerful backend web framework and it‚Äôs quite happy to be paired up with a Vue.js frontend with GraphQL providing the glue.
articles.author: The Dev Space

articles.title: match-sorter 7.0: Deterministic Best-Match Array Sorting
articles.description: If you have an array of items you want to filter and sort ‚Äòintelligently‚Äô and deterministically, this offers a well-described, predictable algorithm. Play with a live CodeSandbox demo.
articles.author: Kent C. Dodds

articles.title: ü§ñ¬†Transformers.js v3: Run Transformers in the Browser
articles.description: A JS port of Hugging Face‚Äôs transformers Python library that can run natural language, vision, and audio machine learning models right in the browser. v3 adds WebGPU support for boosted performance and now supports Node, Deno and Bun too.
articles.author: Hugging Face

articles.title: Fetch Mock 12.0: Mock Requests by the fetch API
articles.description: A flexible API for mocking HTTP requests made by fetch or fetch-imitating libraries. Supports browsers, Node, and web/service workers.
articles.author: Rhys Evans

articles.title: üìä¬†Vizzu 0.14: A Library for Animated Data Visualizations
articles.description: Making visualizations is one thing; animating them is much harder. Vizzu helps you create animated data stories and interactive explorers with a variety of showcase examples for inspiration.
articles.author: Vizzu Inc.

articles.title: eslint-plugin-functional: Rules to Promote Functional Programming
articles.description: This isn‚Äôt for me, but if you want to encourage (or even force) a lack of mutation and a use of FP techniques in your codebase, this could be for you.
articles.author: Jonas Kello

articles.title: Radix Vue: Unstyled, Accessible Components for Vue.js
articles.description: An unofficial Vue port of the popular Radix UI component library. GitHub repo.
articles.author: zernonia et al.

articles.description: Developer IDE firm JetBrains has announced its WebStorm JavaScript/TypeScript IDE is now free for non-commercial use which, notably, also covers paid content creators.
The popular shadcn/ui component library has unveiled a new suite of components for building sidebars.

‚åö Spectra is a hackable smartwatch seeking funding on Kickstarter (but it has passed its initial goal). ESP32-S3 based, it appears able to run JavaScript as shown in the 'dev experience' screenshots.
üôã This year's State of React survey is now open to take until November 19.

‚öõÔ∏è React Native 0.76 ‚Äì A big release. The so-called 'New Architecture' is now used by default (so you can now use all the modern React features in RN too), the React Native DevTools are stable, and build times are faster than ever.
ü•ñ Bun is on a roll.. with three releases in the past week. v1.1.31 added support for node:http2 server and gRPC, v1.1.32 added Node's crypto.hash method, and v1.1.33 was a bug-fix release.
Express.js 5.0 ‚Äì Landed a few weeks ago, but now there's an official post explaining the state of the project which has now passed a comprehensive third party security audit.
Medusa 2.0 ‚Äì A Node.js-powered ecommerce platform.
React Compiler Beta, Turborepo 2.2, ESLint v9.13.0, Deno 2.0.2

articles.title: Possible Future CSS: Tree-Counting Functions and Random Values
articles.description: A look at two possible CSS features (tree counting functions and randomness) from the Level 5 spec, how we can prototype them now, and a look at what their use cases may be ‚Äî via interactive demos.
articles.author: Roma Komarov

articles.title: How Should <selectedoption> Work?
articles.description: A new HTML element! We‚Äôre getting a way to style and customize <select> elements in certain situations, via <selectedoption>. But there are concerns on sync and state issues, and Jake seeks feedback on the practicalities of the intended behavior.
articles.author: Jake Archibald

articles.title: üìä ¬†The State of CSS 2024 Survey Results
articles.description: Sacha Greif notes how 2024 may go down as something of a turning point between classic CSS and ‚Äònew CSS‚Äô ‚Äî what with the many new features and tooling introduced in recent years now reaching a level of widespread browser support, and more importantly, usage. Lots of interesting data points to dig into here (shoutout to the 34 people who said they test their sites on a smartwatch).
articles.author: Devographics

articles.title: So, Your CMS Blew Up. Any Decent WordPress Alternatives Out¬†There?
articles.description: No matter which side of the debate you find yourself, I think it‚Äôs fair to say the mess with WordPress has been universally frustrating in some way or another. As such, Ernie ‚Äî in his typical engaging style ‚Äî outlines some CMS alternatives that you may at least have on your radar if things go further south.
articles.author: Ernie Smith

articles.title: Help Choose the Final Syntax for Masonry in CSS
articles.description: The WebKit team shares a detailed update on where the CSS Working Group is at with the planned introduction of masonry-style layout support in CSS. A lengthy post that highlights design principles, performance considerations, complexity concerns, and more (plus how you can share your thoughts).
articles.author: WebKit

articles.title: Where Web Components Shine
articles.description: Dave shares a quick-fire list of the specific pros and cons of using web components today ‚Äî highlighting strengths, such as low memory usage, style encapsulation, and quick prototyping ‚Äî along with pointing out challenges, including accessibility concerns.
articles.author: Dave Rupert

articles.title: Smarter than 'Ctrl+F': Linking Directly to Web Page Content
articles.description: A powerful feature of the modern web platform that allows for precise linking to specific text within a web page without the need to add an anchor.
articles.author: Ahmad Alfy

articles.title: CSS min() All The Things
articles.description: Experimentations with the CSS min() function, exploring its flexibility with different units to determine ‚Äúif it is the be-all, end-all for responsiveness‚Äù.
articles.author: Victor Ayomipo

articles.title: How Microsoft Edge is Replacing React with Web Components
articles.description: As part of their WebUI 2.0 project, the Edge browser team is on a mission to swap out React UI components with native web platform components, largely for performance reasons.
articles.author: Richard MacManus (The New Stack)

articles.title: Hyper-Responsive Web Components
articles.description: Dives into the nuance of getting an embeddable call-to-action sign up component working in as many places as possible (any position, and viewport, any amount of content).
articles.author: Trys Mudford

articles.title: Khoshnus: A Library to 'Bring Life' to SVG Text
articles.description: A library for ‚Äòbringing life to static text in an artistic way.‚Äô Essentially it takes SVG text and animates it into existence on your page.
articles.author: Amer Jabar

articles.title: CSS Spring Easing Generator: Make Generating Spring Easings More Intuitive
articles.description: The tool allows you to customize two main settings: perceptual duration (in milliseconds) and bounce (%). You an also select from three presets and the code is generated as CSS variables for use with CSS animations.
articles.author: Kevin Grajeda

articles.title: HEX¬∑P3: Quickly Convert HEX Colors to the Display P3 Color¬†Space
articles.description: The resulting code uses the relatively new CSS color() function with the display-p3, which according to the spec, ‚Äòenables more vibrant greens and reds than the sRGB color gamut‚Äô.
articles.author: Wojtek Witkowski

articles.title: Emoji-Fallback.js: Provide Support for Emojis on All Browsers
articles.description: Replaces emoji characters with emoji images on devices that don't have emoji support.
articles.author: Jared Van Valkengoed
